Award.AwardTitle: Assistive Technology Projects for Persons with Disabilities

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Murfee, Walter
Proposal Number: 1159300

Since 1987, the senior capstone design course in the Department of Biomedical Engineering at Tulane University has been focused on designing technologies for persons in the community with disabilities. Over 700 students and 180 clients have benefited from this design experience. This proposal requests support for team project supply costs that will enable the continuation of this course. In conjunction with their coursework in the sequence BMEN 4030-4040 Team Design Projects, biomedical engineering undergraduate students will form multidisciplinary teams to address the needs of individuals with disabilities in their therapeutic, work, home, or school environments. The teams, working with their client directly or working with their client's institution will design, construct, evaluate, and deliver a technology or device that solves an immediate client need. The primary objectives of our senior design course are to provide a meaningful design experience for biomedical engineering students, enhance the professional development of Tulane biomedical engineering students and provide assistive technologies or devices that are not otherwise available to individuals with disabilities or institutions serving them.

The intellectual merit of the program includes facilitation of the transition of biomedical students from school to practice and the development and dissemination of new knowledge. Students will apply formal knowledge learned in courses to real engineering problems that require the ethical perspective and conduct required of the engineering profession. Throughout the year long course and related design process, student teams will communicate their progress via formal reports, presentation of prototypes at a design show, design contest entries, potential patents and publication of abstracts and papers.

The broader impacts resulting from this work include the enhancement of education infrastructure, providing a benefit to the society, and advancing discovery and understanding while at the same time promoting teaching, training, and learning. The student design projects will directly enhance the lives of individual clients. Clients will receive technologies that solve real problems limiting their daily function. In addition, design projects will be disseminated to enable a wide audience to use these solutions. The guided interactions between students, instructors, therapists, and clients will permit the sharing of knowledge from multiple perspectives and areas of expertise. The student participants will also gain greater awareness of the problems of individuals with disabilities and the ability to communicate with and about people who have disabilities.

Institution.Name: Tulane University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: ADMINISTRATORS OF THE TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND, THE

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 1987, the senior capstone design course in the Department of Biomedical Engineering at Tulane University has been focused on designing technologies for persons in the community with disabilities. This design experience has benefited over 800 students and 200 clients and its continuation over the past 5 years was made possible by NSF funding. During the grant period, the senior undergraduate design course involved 105 students, 23 student teams and 23 projects. The overall purpose of the funded capstone design course was to integrate program curriculum and provide hands-on experience with real problems. Students working in multi-disciplinary teams addressed the needs of individuals with disabilities, their caretakers and related medical problems. The projects resulted in 10 provisional patents and ranged from improving the lives of disabled individuals with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) to innovative smart devices for physical therapy feedback.  Project completion required the application rapid prototyping with the use of “maker space” technologies (i.e. three-dimensional printers and laser cutters), product specification, electronic circuit design, testing, assembly, finite element analysis, signal analysis, and software development. Intellectual merit entailed an experiential transition for biomedical students from “school” to “practice” and the development and dissemination of new knowledge. Students applied formal knowledge learned in courses to real engineering problems that required an ethical and professional perspective. Throughout the 2 semester course students experienced the design process and communicated their progress via formal reports, prototypes at design shows, and design competitions. The broader impacts resulting from this work included the enhancement of education infrastructure, providing a benefit to the society, and advancing discovery and understanding while at the same time promoting teaching, training, and learning. The student design projects directly enhanced the lives of individual clients or led to the development of technologies aimed at improving clinical treatment of populations of persons with disabilities. In addition, the senior undergraduates and their projects provided a conduit for forming new interdisciplinary connections by exposing students to multiple Department of Biomedical Engineering faculty, School of Business faculty, Tulane’s Goldman Office of Disability Services, the Tulane Center for Advanced Medical Simulation & Team Training, Tulane’s Office of Technology Transfer and Intellectual Property Development, local nursing homes, local clinicians, and local entrepreneurs.


Last Modified: 08/13/2018
Modified by: Walter Murfee

Students working in multi-disciplinary teams addressed the needs of individuals with disabilities, their caretakers and related medical problems. Intellectual merit entailed an experiential transition for biomedical students from "school" to "practice" and the development and dissemination of new knowledge. Students applied formal knowledge learned in courses to real engineering problems that required an ethical and professional perspective. Throughout the 2 semester course students experienced the design process and communicated their progress via formal reports, prototypes at design shows, and design competitions. In addition, the senior undergraduates and their projects provided a conduit for forming new interdisciplinary connections by exposing students to multiple Department of Biomedical Engineering faculty, School of Business faculty, Tulane?s Goldman Office of Disability Services, the Tulane Center for Advanced Medical Simulation & Team Training, Tulane?s Office of Technology Transfer and Intellectual Property Development, local nursing homes, local clinicians, and local entrepreneurs.
